comments.commentBody: I'm the director of publications at Northeast Foundation for Children, developers of the Responsive Classroom approach, and am interested in your reactions to our DVD about time-out. I can see why this particular scene might appear contrary to the overall message of the Responsive Classroom approach. We’re always trying to improve our resources for educators and would appreciate hearing from you and anyone else who would like to share feedback about our publications. You can email me at marybeth@responsiveclassroom.org.

While I have learned about several positive points regarding the Responsive Classroom Approach, I would like to call attention to a slice of this program that I personally find disturbing: their use of "time-out." I can only speak from what I saw in one of their DVD's and from what I have seen through teachers that have been trained by their staff to use such an approach - which mimics what is on the DVD. I can quote the dialogues verbatim, after having watched this DVD several times and the speech that teachers use in their Responsive Classroom schools. I often show the DVD to my graduate students without expressing my opinion and I have consistently gotten negative and confused reviews of, not only the approach, but also of what they are attempting to "teach" - "to help children gain self control." One child, honestly frustrated for not having done anything to warrant a trip to a "refill station" in the corner of the classroom, with an empty shelf and, what looks like, "a time-out chair," asks the teacher what happens if they didn't do anything wrong. Do they still need to go to the refill station? The teacher answers, "Yes!" "First you go to the refill station, then we talk about it." This seems contrary to everything that the author of this article tries to convey. I have also asked children who live in Greenfield, MA, who attend schools using this approach, what "the refill station" was all about. Their answer? "It's a time-out corner."

So true. Additionaly, apart from re-electing our President, we must eliminate the "American Taliban" from Congress. For this country to succeed,not only do we need, we MUST have a unified Congress- One that can identify with the 47%.

The Republican leadership including Mr. Romney do not care at all about Medicare, or for that matter social security, or indeed any other government program. These well heeled conservative leaders only purpose is to retain and increase their power and wealth. To that end they need to win elections and to do that they have reached out to the disaffected haters of government. They argue that government is the problem and the cause of the nation's problems. It does not matter that none of what they say is true, what does matter is that it gathers votes like a magnet gathers iron filings.
Gaining the White House is a door to dismantling the EPA and other regulatory agencies that control banking and energy. That is the means to open new and enormous unencumbered channels of wealth for big industry.
None of this is about the working class or poor. None of it is about access to food, education, or health care. It is only about controlling and extending their power and wealth.

At least 40 people have dies do far including a 4 month old baby and you see this as fun?
Human beings are the only animals who go TOWARD danger while the rest of the animal kingdom heads for high ground and inland.

I guess that our government agencies could do as Russia did...They did not warn villages of a flood that killed hundreds!

I've worked 45 years in trauma with civil defense units...I would rather see over-planning every time and never lose one person or pet.

Hurricane/Tropical Storm Irene, just last year, had the fifth highest toll in property damage in US history at $15 billion dollars.  Most of the damage was from inland river flooding which was not covered by home owner's insurance and only certain flood places were assisted by FEMA.  $15 billion is a SUBSTANTIAL amount of money, especially to those of us impacted in the Northeast in places like the Hudson Valley, Vermont and Pennsylvania.  Better construction helps in a hurricane (see post-Andrew building codes in FL), but flood waters six feet high will come into your house no matter how well you build it.

This is something you can actually google. Look for flood inundation zones in your neighborhood. It will tell you street by street what will flood.

For example:
http://brooklyn.about.com/

I lived in Honolulu for 25 years and all phone books showed flood inundation areas for all coastlines.

Sandy is a popular unisex name; the male version can be a diminutive of "Alexander," "Alasdair," "Sandipan", "Sanford," or "Santiago," while the female version is a diminutive for "Sandra" or less commonly "Alexandra". The female name may also be spelled "Sandi" or "Sandie".

Wikipedia!

As Bill Hicks reminded us, dinosaur bones were put there to test your faith ("You test my faith dude!").

Whether flood or fire, what matters is true biblical believers will be bodily brought up above the fray to return to a cleansed earth & carbon emissions have absolutely no possible impact on the weather...
Can I get a amen?

Where's Noah when we need him...

Please don't use outdoor camp stoves and gas lanterns  inside your homes.  Please do check on your neighbors especially elderly neighbors.  Stay warm and safe.
Please don't use outdoor camp stoves and gas lanterns  inside your homes.  Please do check on your neighbors especially elderly neighbors.  Stay warm and safe.

As a Title I instructor, I agree completely that social education is essential to pave the way for student academic gains. The difficulty is that not every principal believes this is a valid use of academic time. I have often felt that I was sneeking in these moments for class meetings or cooperative games, especially during the drive to prepare students for state exams. For students who lack cooperation skills, empathy, and trust, academic gains are stifled. If a student finds their classroom to be a safe supportive place to learn, the sky is the limit in terms of their social and academic success, but too often the social success of the child is overlook in the interest of time.

Drove from Knoxville to central New Jersey over the past two days and saw convoy after convoy of utility trucks --cherry pickers, drills for poles, etc-- heading north towards Sandy's impact area. Looks like the system is working to repair the expected damage as quickly as possible.
That's good to hear!

Drove from Knoxville to central New Jersey over the past two days and saw convoy after convoy of utility trucks --cherry pickers, drills for poles, etc-- heading north towards Sandy's impact area. Looks like the system is working to repair the expected damage as quickly as possible.

I am in Northern Westchester, where the weather is cloudy but calm, I think that this storm will affect mainly low-lying, coastal areas. The NWS tells me that we'll have 3 inches of rain in 5 days - no big deal up here, where a summer storm can dump that much in a few hours - and lots of wind - meaning some trees down.

I think that Bloomberg made the right decision. The coverage, however, seems exaggerated. If I lived on the waterfront, or in direct path of the landfall, I'd get out. The rest of this stuff seems alarmist.

Where I live (Southern California) we had about 8 hours of sustained winds of 40 mph with gusts that exceeded that. The damage was nothing short of amazing and the power outages lasted over a week for some people. The forecasts I'm seeing for the affected areas there are for 36 hours of punishing winds. Trees that can handle 6 hours of winds can't necessarily handle 6 times that.
RMC, my friend, you can NEVER exaggerate the power of a hurricane --- it can change to "more dangerous" in the blink of an eye!

RMC:

It is 1 AM on October 30, about 24 hours after your post.

There have been a number of deaths (about 13), tunnels and other subterranean structures have flooded, power is out for millions as I write.

Still think this "alarmist"??

I didn't think so.

My thoughts and prayers are with my fellow Americans.
